question: Come left a little. She's right in front of us, eighteen meters. Fifteen. Thirteen... you should see it.
answer: It still gets me every time. Thanks, Tolya. Work with me, here. It still gets me every time... to see the sad ruin of the great ship sitting here, where she landed at 2:30 in the morning, April 15, 1912, after her long fall from the world above.

question: You are so full of shit, boss.
answer: Dive nine. Here we are again on the deck of Titanic... two and a half miles down. The pressure is three tons per square inch, enough to crush us like a freight train going over an ant if our hull fails. These windows are nine inches thick and if they go, it's sayonara in two microseconds. Right. Let's go to work.

question: Walkin' the dog. I'm in the sitting room. Heading for bedroom B-54.
answer: Stay off the floor. Don't stir it up like you did yesterday.

question: I'm tryin' boss. I'm crossing the bedroom.
answer: Okay, I want to see what's under that wardrobe door. Easy, Lewis. Take it slow.

question: Ooohh daddy-oh, are you seein' what I'm seein'?
answer: Oh baby baby baby.

question: Who's the best? Say it.
answer: You are, Lewis. Well, here it is, the moment of truth. Here's where we find out if the time, the sweat, the money spent to charter this ship and these subs, to come out here to the middle of the North Atlantic... were worth it. If what we think is in that same... is in that safe... it will be. Shit.

question: You know, boss, this happened to Geraldo and his career never recovered.
answer: You send out what I tell you when I tell you. I'm signing your paychecks, not 60 minutes. Now get set up for the uplink.

question: There's a satellite call for you.
answer: Bobby, we're launching. See these submersibles here, going in the water? Take a message.

question: No, trust me, you want to take this call.
answer: This is Brock Lovett. What can I do for you, Mrs... ?

question: Rose Calvert.
answer: ... Mrs. Calvert?

question: She says she's Rose DeWitt Bukater, right? Rose DeWitt Bukater died on the Titanic. At the age of 17. If she'd've lived, she'd be over a hundred now.
answer: A hundred and one next month.

question: Okay, so she's a very old goddamned liar. I traced her as far back as the 20's... she was working as an actress in L.A. An actress. Her name was Rose Dawson. Then she married a guy named Calvert, moved to Cedar Rapids, had two kids. Now Calvert's dead, and from what I've heard Cedar Rapids is dead.
answer: And everyobody who knows about the diamond is supposed to be dead... or on this ship. But she knows about it. And I want to hear what she has to say. Got it?

question: S'cuse me, I have to go check our supply of Depends.
answer: Is your stateroom alright?

question: Oh, yes. There, that's nice. I have to have my pictures when I travel. And Freddy of course.
answer: Would you like anything?

question: I should like to see my drawing.
answer: Louis the Sixteenth wore a fabulous stone, called the Blue Diamond of the Crown, which disappeared in 1792, about the time Louis lost everything from the neck up. The theory goes that the crown diamond was chopped too... recut into a heart-like shape... and it became Le Coeur de la Mer. The Heart of the Ocean. Today it would be worth more than the Hope Diamond.

question: If your grandma is who she says she is, she was wearing the diamond the day Titanic sank.
answer: I don't want your money, Mr. Lovett. I know how hard it is for people who care greatly for money to give some away.

question: Deal.
answer: This was mine. How extraordinary! It looks the same as the last time I saw it. The reflection has changed a bit. My mother's brooch. She wanted to go back for it. Caused quite a fuss.

question: Thank you for that fine forensic analysis, Mr. Bodine. Of course the experience of it was somewhat less clinical.
answer: Will you share it with us?

question: No!
answer: Tell us, Rose.

question: It's been 84 years...
answer: Just tell us what you can--

question: All part of my charm, Ruth. At any rate, it was my darling fiancee's beauty rituals which made us late.
answer: You told me to change.

question: I couldn't let you wear black on sailing day, sweetpea. It's bad luck.
answer: I felt like black.

question: The moment of truth boys. Somebody's life's about to change. Let's see... Fabrizio's got niente. Olaf, you've got squat. Sven, uh oh... two pair... mmm.
answer: What sorry? What you got? You lose my money?? Ma va fa'n culo testa di cazzo--

question: Sorry, you're not gonna see your mama again for a long time...
answer: Porca Madonna!! YEEAAAAA!!!

question: Goin' home... to the land o' the free and the home of the real hot-dogs! On the TITANIC!! We're ridin' in high style now! We're practically goddamned royalty, ragazzo mio!!
answer: You see? Is my destinio!! Like I told you. I go to l'America!! To be a millionaire!!

question: Don't do it.
answer: Stay back! Don't come any closer!

question: Take my hand. I'll pull you back in.
answer: No! Stay where you are. I mean it. I'll let go.

question: No you won't.
answer: What do you mean no I won't? Don't presume to tell me what I will and will not do. You don't know me.

question: You would have done it already. Now come on, take my hand.
answer: You're distracting me. Go away.

question: I can't. I'm involved now. If you let go I have to jump in after you.
answer: Don't be absurd. You'll be killed.

question: I'm a good swimmer.
answer: The fall alone would kill you.

question: It would hurt. I'm not saying it wouldn't. To be honest I'm a lot more concerned about the water being so cold.
answer: How cold?

question: Ever been to Wisconsin? Well they have some of the coldest winters around, and I grew up there, near Chippewa Falls. Once when I was a kid me and my father were ice-fishing out on Lake Wissota... ice-fishing's where you chop a hole in the--
answer: I know what ice fishing is!

question: Sorry. Just... you look like kind of an indoor girl. Anyway, I went through some thin ice and I'm tellin' ya, water that cold... like that right down there... it hits you like a thousand knives all over your body. You can't breath, you can't think... least not about anything but the pain.
answer: You're crazy.

question: That's what everybody says. But with all due respect, I'm not the one hanging off the back of a ship. Come on. You don't want to do this. Give me your hand.
answer: Alright.

question: I'm Jack Dawson.
answer: HELP! HELP!!

question: What made you think you could put your hands on my fiancee?! Look at me, you filth! What did you think you were doing?!
answer: Cal, stop! It was an accident.

question: An accident?!
answer: It was... stupid really. I was leaning over and I slipped. I was leaning way over, to see the... ah... propellers. And I slipped and I would have gone overboard... and Mr. Dawson here saved me and he almost went over himself.

question: I intended to save this till the engagement gals next week. But I thought tonight, perhaps a reminder of my feeling for you...
answer: My God... Cal. Is it a--

question: Daimond. Yes it is. 56 carats. It was once worn by Louis the Sixteenth. They call it Le Coeur de la Mer, the--
answer: The Heart of the Ocean. Cal, it's... it's overwhelming.

question: Well you tell the hand I need another two days! Bobby, Bobby, Bobby... we're close! I smell it. I smell ice. She had the diamond on... now we just have to find out where it wound up. I just gotta work her a bit more. Okay? Hey, Lizzy. I need to talk to you for a second.
answer: Don't you mean work me?

question: Look, I'm running out of time. I need your help.
answer: I'm not going to help you browbeat my hundred and one year old grandmother. I came down here to tell you to back off. What?

question: That's the shape my hand's gonna be when I hold that thing. You understand? I'm not leaving here without it.
answer: Look, Brock, she's going to do this her way, in her own time. Don't forget, she contacted you. She's out here for her own reasons, God knows what they are.

question: Hello Jack.
answer: Hello again.

question: Could I speak to you in private?
answer: Uh, yes. Of course. After you. So, you got a name by the way?

question: Rose. Rose DeWitt Bukater.
answer: That's quite a moniker. I may hafta get you to write that down.

question: Mr. Dawson, I--
answer: Jack.

question: Jack... I feel like such an idiot. It took me all morning to get up the nerve to face you.
answer: Well, here you are.

question: Here I am. I... I want to thank you for what you did. Not just for... for pulling me back. But for your discretion.
answer: You're welcome. Rose.

question: Look, I know what you must be thinking! Poor little rich girl. What does she know about misery?
answer: That's not what I was thinking. What I was thinking was... what could have happened to hurt this girl so much she though she had no way out.

question: I don't... it wasn't just one thing. It was everything. It was them, it was their whole world. And I was trapped in it, like an insect in amber.
answer: Uh huh. They'll be sorry. 'Course you'll be dead. That penguin last night, is he one of them?

question: Penguin? Oh, Cal! He is them.
answer: Is he your boyfriend?

question: Worse I'm afraid.
answer: Gawd look at that thing! You would have gone straight to the bottom. So you feel like you're stuck on a train you can't get off 'cause you're marryin' this fella.

question: Yes, exactly!
answer: So don't marry him.

question: If only it were that simple.
answer: It is that simple.

question: Oh, Jack... please don't judge me until you've seen my world.
answer: Well, I guess I will tonight.

question: What's this?
answer: Just some sketches.

question: May I? Jack, these are quite good! Really, they are.
answer: Well, they didn't think too much of 'em in Paree.

question: Oh no! Oh, I'm so sorry. Truly!
answer: Well, they didn't think too much of 'em in Paree. I just seem to spew 'em out. Besides, they're not worth a damn anyway.

question: Well, well...
answer: Yup. That's one of the great things about Paris. Lots of girls willing take their clothes off.

question: You liked this woman. You used her several times.
answer: She had beautiful hands. I see you.

question: And...?
answer: You wouldn'ta jumped.

question: I'm sorry. Really... I am.
answer: Well, alright. There's something in me, Jack. I feel it. I don't know what it is, whether I should be an artist, or, I don't know... a dancer. Like Isadora Duncan.... a wild pagan spirit... ...or a moving picture actress! So then what, Mr. Wandering Jack?

question: Well, then logging got to be too much like work, so I went down to Los Angelas to the pier in Santa Monica. That's a swell place, they even have a rollercoaster. I sketched portraits there for ten cents a piece.
answer: A whole ten cents?!

question: Alright, we're going. We'll drink cheap beer and go on the rollercoaster until we throw up and we'll ride horses on the beach... right in the surf... but you have to ride like a cowboy, none of that side-saddle stuff.
answer: You mean one leg on each side? Scandalous! Can you show me?

question: Sure. If you like. They didn't teach you that in finishing school? Here, it's easy. Watch closely. Your turn. Nope, that was pitiful. Here, like this... you hawk it down... HHHNNNK!... then roll it on your tongue, up to the front, like thith, then a big breath and PLOOOW!! You see the range on that thing? That was great!
answer: Mother, may I introduce Jack Dawson.

question: Jack, must you go?
answer: Time for my coach to turn back into a pumpkin. Want to go to a real party?

question: May I cut in, miss?
answer: You're still my best girl, Cora.

question: I don't know the steps.
answer: Just move with me. Don't think.

question: Wait... stop!
answer: How you two doin'?

question: Boys, boys! Did I ever tell you the one about the Swede and the Irishman goin' to the whorehouse?
answer: So, you think you're big tough men? Let's see you do this. Oooowww! I haven't done that in years. Isn't it magnificent? So grand and endless. They're such small people, Jack... my crowd. They think they're giants on the earth, but they're not even dust in God's eye. They live inside this little tiny champagne bubble... and someday the bubble's going to burst.

question: You're not one of them. There's been a mistake.
answer: A mistake?

question: Uh huh. You got mailed to the wrong address. That was a long one. My father used to say that whenever you saw one, it was a soul going to heaven.
answer: I like that. Aren't we supposed to wish on it?

question: What would you wish for?
answer: Something I can't have.

question: I had hoped you would come to me last night.
answer: I was tired.

question: Yes. Your exertions below decks were no doubt exausting. You will never behave like that again! Do you understand?
answer: I'm not some foreman in your mills than you can command! I am your fiancee--

question: Yes! You are! And my wife... in practice, if not yet by law. So you will honor me, as a wife is required to honor her husband! I will not be made out a fool! Is this in any way unclear?
answer: We... had a little accident. I'm sorry, Trudy.

question: We... had a little accident. I'm sorry, Trudy.
answer: You are not to see that boy again, do you understand me Rose? I forbid it!

question: Oh, stop it, Mother. You'll give yourself a nosebleed. Of course I know it's gone. You remind me every day!
answer: Your father left us nothing but a legacy of bad debts hidden by a good name. And that name is the only card we have to play. I don't understand you. It is a fine match with Hockley, and it will insure our survival. Do you want to se me working as a seamstress? Is that what you want? Do you want to see our fine things sold at an auction, our memories scattered to the winds? My God, Rose, how can you be so selfish?

question: It's so unfair.
answer: Of course it's unfair! We're women. Our choices are never easy.

question: I was just here last night... don't you remember?
answer: Mr. Hockley and Mrs. DeWitt Bukater continue to be most appreciative of your assistance. They asked me to give you this in gratitude--

question: I don't want money, I--
answer: --and also to remind you that you hold a third class ticket and your presence here is no longer appropriate.

question: I just need to talk to Rose for a--
answer: Gentlemen, please see that Mr. Dawson gets back where he belongs.

question: Jack, this is impossible. I can't see you.
answer: Rose, you're no picnic... you're a spoiled little brat even, but under that you're a strong, pure heart, and you're the most amazingly astounding girl I've ever known and--

question: Jack, I--
answer: No wait. Let me try to get this out. You're amazing... and I know I have nothing to offer you, Rose. I know that. But I'm involved now. You jump, I jump, remember? I can't turn away without knowin' that you're goin' to be alright.

question: You're making this very hard. I'll be fine. Really.
answer: I don't think so. They've got you in a glass jar like some butterfly, and you're goin' to die if you don't break out. Maybe not right away, 'cause you're strong. But sooner or later the fire in you is goin' to go out.

question: It's not up to you to save me, Jack.
answer: You're right. Only you can do that.

question: Will this light do? Don't artists need good light?
answer: Isn't he great... the use of color? I saw him once... through a hole in this garden fence in Giverny.

question: Cal insist on luggin this thing everywhere.
answer: Should I be expecting him anytime soon?

question: Not as long as the cigars and brandy hold out.
answer: What is it? A sapphire?

question: A diamond. A very rare diamond, called the Heart of the Ocean. I want you to draw me like your French girl. Wearing this. The last thing I need is another picture of me looking like a china doll. As a paying customer, I expect to get what I want. Tell me when it looks right to you.
answer: Uh... just bend your left leg a little and... and lower your head. Eyes to me. That's it.

question: I don't think I've ever seen such a flat calm, in 24 years at sea.
answer: Yes, like a mill pond. Not a breath of wind.

question: It's make the bergs harder to see, with no breaking water at the base.
answer: Mmmmm. Well, I'm off. Maintain speed and heading, Mr. Lightoller.

question: Yes sir.
answer: And wake me, of course, if anything becomes in the slightest degree doubtful.

question: Come on! Take us down. Quickly, quickly!
answer: Pretty tough for a valet, this fella.

question: He's an ex-Pinkerton. Cal's father hired him to keep Cal out of trouble... to make sure he always got back to the hotel with his wallet and watch, after some crawl through the less reputable parts of town...
answer: Kinda like we're doin' right now-- uh oh! After you, m'lady. Where to, Miss?

question: To the stars.
answer: Are you nervous?

question: What was that, Mr. Murdoch?
answer: An iceberg, sir. I put her hard a' starboard and run the engines full astern, but it was too close. I tried to port around it, but she hi... and

question: Close the emergency doors.
answer: The doors are closed.

question: A five degree list in less than ten minutes.
answer: Why have we stopped?

question: We've struck ice.
answer: Well, do you think the ship is seriously damaged?

question: Water 14 feet above the keel in ten minutes... in the forepeak... in all three holds... and in boiler room six.
answer: That's right.

question: Five compartments. She can stay afloat with the first four compartments breached. But not five. Not five. As she goes down by the head the water will spill over the tops of the bulkheads... at E Deck... from one to the next... back and back. There's no stopping it.
answer: The pumps--

question: Anyone in here?
answer: Mr. Andrews, thank God! Where would the Master at Arms take someone under arrest?!

question: What? You have to get to a boat right away!
answer: No! I'll do this with or without your help, sir. But without will take longer. Bottom, left, right. I have it.

question: Hurry, Rose.
answer: I'm through with being polite, goddamnit!! I may never be polite the rest of my life! Now take me down!!

question: Left, crew passage. Right, right... right. Jack? Jaaacckk??
answer: ROSE!! In here!

question: Jack, Jack, Jack... I'm sorry, I'm so sorry.
answer: That guy Lovejoy put it in my pocket.

question: I know, I know.
answer: See if you can find a key for these. Try those drawers. It's a little brass one. So... how did you find out I didn't do it?

question: I didn't. There's no key in here.
answer: You have to go for help. I'll wait here.

question: Hello? Somebody?! Help me! We need help!
answer: Come on, then, let's get you topside, miss, that's right.

question: Wait. Wait! I need your help! There's--
answer: No need for panic, miss. Come along!

question: No, let me go! You're going the wrong way!
answer: To Hell with you!

question: Compliments of the Chippewa Falls Dawsons. Let's go.
answer: We can't leave him.

question: Come on. Back! Go back!!
answer: No! Not that way! Come back!

question: Wait! Wait! Help us! Unlock the gate.
answer: Help us! Please!

question: You wanna walk a little faster through that valley, fella? Come on, Rose. We can't expect God to do all the work for us. We have to move! Come on! I've got you!
answer: I trust you.

question: Swim, Rose! SWIM! Keep swimming. Keep moving. Come one, you can do it. Look for something floating. Some debris... wood... anything.
answer: It's so cold.

question: I know. I know. Help me, here. Look around.
answer: What's that?

question: It's getting quiet.
answer: Just a few more minutes. It'll take them a while to get the boats organized... I don't know about you, but I intend to write a strongly worded letter to the White Star Line about all this.

question: I love you Jack.
answer: No... don't say your good-byes, Rose. Don't you give up. Don't do it.

question: I'm so cold.
answer: You're going to get out of this... you're going to go on and you're going to make babies and watch them grow and you're going to die an old lady, warm in your bed. Not here. Not this night. Do you understand me?

question: I can't feel my body.
answer: Rose, listen to me. Listen. Winning that ticket was the best thing that ever happened to me. It brought me to you. And I'm thankful, Rose. I'm thankful. You must do me this honor... promise me you will survive... that you will never give up... no matter what happens... no matter how hopeless... promise me now, and never let go of that promise.

question: I promise.
answer: Never let go.

question: Yes, I lived. How awkward for you.
answer: Rose... your mother and I have been looking for you--

question: Please don't. Don't talk. Just listen. We will make a deal, since that is something you understand. From this moment you do not exist for me, nor I for you. You shall not see me again. And you will not attempt to find me. In return I will keep my silence. Your actions last night need never come to light, and you will get to keep the honor you have carefully purchased. Is this in any way unclear? Tell her that her daughter died with the Titanic.
answer: You're precious to me, Rose.
